title: Lake Liepāja
text:
Lake Liepāja (, formerly Lake Libava, ) is the fifth-largest lake in <a href="Latvia">Latvia</a>, located near <a href="Liep%C4%81ja">Liepāja</a> in the <a href="Liep%C4%81ja%20District">Liepāja District</a>. The total area of the lake is 37.15 km2, and it has a length of 16.2 km, average depth of 2.0 m, and a shoreline of 44.6 km.
Lake Liepāja is a pod-shaped shallow <a href="eutrophic">eutrophic</a> coastal lake with extensive areas of emergent vegetation (<a href="Phragmites">Phragmites</a>, <a href="Typha">Typha</a>, <a href="Scirpus">Scirpus</a>, <a href="Sparganium">Sparganium</a>), surrounded by seasonally flooded meadows and arable land. Polders and dams enclose most of the wetland area. The lake has 14 species of fish: <a href="esox">pike</a>, <a href="Rutilus">roach</a>, <a href="perch">perch</a>, <a href="bream">bream</a>, <a href="crucian%20carp">crucian carp</a>, <a href="tench">tench</a>, <a href="eel">eel</a>, <a href="vimba">vimba</a>, <a href="burbot">burbot</a>, <a href="carp">carp</a>, <a href="zander">zander</a>, <a href="smelt%20%28fish%29">smelt</a>, <a href="bitterling">bitterling</a>, and <a href="rudd">rudd</a>. In May only licensed fishing is allowed. The price of a licence is 10 <a href="Latvian%20lats">LVL</a> (about $20). From 1977 to 1999 the lake was an <a href="ornithological">ornithological</a> preserve with 2 species of birds: <a href="swan">swan</a>s and <a href="duck">duck</a>s. Since 2004 the lake has been included on the European Union <a href="Natura%202000">Natura 2000</a> protected territories list. In 2008, a nature protection plan for Lake Liepāja was developed by the <a href="Grontmij">Grontmij Carl Bro</a> company.
Islands.
Lake Liepāja has 13 islands, the most notable of which are Atteku(-as), Zirgu, Pērkona, Putnu (kalva) and Cionas. On the east shore of the lake is the Friča <a href="Grove%20%28nature%29">grove</a>, and on the west shore near <a href="P%C4%93rkone">Pērkone</a> is the Reiņu Forest ().
History.
Historically, Lake Liepāja was connected with <a href="Lake%20Tosmare">Lake Tosmare</a> by Vernen Creek, but in the 20th century the creek was filled in. Later in the 20th century the Fortress Canal (, ), which connects the lake to the Lake Tosmare and the sea, was dug. In the second half of the 20th century, the plant <a href="Liep%C4%81jas%20Metalurgs">Liepājas Metalurgs</a> built the Golodov Dam to separate the polluted part of the lake from the rest of the lake.
Rivers.
The Ālande, Bārta, Otaņķe (Brūnupe), Līčupe, Orbupe, and Dorupe rivers flow into the lake.
